findings.title: Unprotected functions
findings.description: Several functions marked with have no access modifiers, which could lead to unauthorized access.

findings.title: Payable functions
findings.description: Functions marked with are payable, which might introduce reentrancy risks if not properly handled.

findings.title: Locked or sensitive data
findings.description: Variables and functions marked with or may be sensitive or locked, but their security implications are unclear without more context.

findings.title: Access control
findings.description: Functions with onlyOwner modifiers could potentially allow unauthorized access or modifications if the owner address is not properly secured.

findings.title: Reentrancy
findings.description: Functions like swapTokensForEth, swapETHForTokens, and _transfer may be vulnerable to reentrancy attacks if not properly implemented.

findings.title: Unchecked user input
findings.description: Functions that accept user-inputted values, such as setTaxFeePercent or setMaxTxAmount, could be exploited if the inputs are not properly validated.

findings.title: Lack of input validation
findings.description: Functions like _approve, _transfer, and addLiquidity may be vulnerable to attacks if they do not validate their inputs correctly.

findings.title: Unsecured use of sensitive functions
findings.description: Functions like withdraw or transferToAddressETH could be exploited if they are not properly secured or access-controlled.

findings.title: Owner Privileges
findings.description: Active smart contract owner privileges constitute an elevated impact to smart contractâ€™s safety and security.

findings.title: Max Transaction Change
findings.description: Smart contract owner can change max transaction amount, potentially setting it to zero.

findings.title: Max Wallet Amount Change
findings.description: Smart contract owner can change max wallet amount, potentially setting it to zero.
